block.p: Milestones Not content with celebrating the 30th anniversary of his debut with the New York Philharmonic, Sir Colin Davis will officially assume his position as the orchestra's principal guest conductor when he leads the first of three subscription concerts tonight at Avery Fisher Hall. In this role, Sir Colin will spend at least three weeks each season with the Philharmonic.

In this role, Sir Colin will spend at least three weeks each season with the Philharmonic.

Success Story Flabbergasted when its letter to Queen Elizabeth II led to an invitation, a previously unknown teen-age British rock band will perform tomorrow at a 50th-birthday celebration for Prince Charles. The Daily Mail reported yesterday that the four members of Al!ve, who are 16 and 17, wrote: ''Dear Your Majesty. We are four good lads who don't do drugs, aren't scruffy and don't use foul language (maybe that's where we've been going wrong!). Anyway if you can give us a break it would really be cool. With our love to you and the royal family.''

Rerun What are they studying at Dartmouth? Tomorrow through Sunday, scholars will gather on the campus in Hanover, N.H., to discuss the Russian filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein (1898-1948). The conference ''Eisenstein at 100: A Reconsideration'' asks to what extent a world that has witnessed the decay of the Soviet Union can still value Eisenstein, who worked under official auspices and produced films like ''Alexander Nevsky'' that ostensibly upheld Soviet ideals.

Reparation To return to their rightful owners more than 171 paintings looted by the Nazis, the French Foreign Ministry is distributing an illustrated catalogue of the missing works to museums and art galleries worldwide. Most of the works are by Flemish and Dutch masters and were seized during World War II from Adolphe Schloss, a Jew.

New Chapter One of Sweden's leading literary critics, Horace Engdahl, has been chosen to lead the Swedish Academy, which awards the Nobel Prize in Literature. Mr. Engdahl, 49, will succeed Sture Allen as the academy's permanent secretary. Mr. Allen, who has held the post since 1986, turns 70 on Dec. 31 and is retiring.

Prized The Atlantic Theater Company has won the 1998 Jujamcyn Theaters Award, carrying a $50,000 prize. The annual award goes to a resident theater that has made an outstanding contribution to the development of creative talent for the theater. Recent productions by the Atlantic, an artistic ensemble founded in 1985 by David Mamet and William H. Macy, are ''The Beauty Queen of Leenane'' by Martin McDonagh, ''Mojo'' by Jez Butterworth and ''Edmond'' by Mr. Mamet.
